I believe that the use of this technology would be valuable to use in a classroom full of students. I believe this because instructors must know what their students emotions are like toward the subject being taught. For example, let's say a students emotion is bored, the taecher would then know what his students emotion is like. The instructor may be able to give a 2 to 5 minute survey to his students based on what he can do to improve his teaching skills. Which would therefor give his students a better environment to work. The prompt explained a somewhat new computer software that could recognize emotions. It explains what the software can do and how it works. 'The process begins when the computer constructs a 3-D computer model of the face; all 44 major muscles in the model must move like a human muscle. Movement of one or more muscle is called an "action unit."'(D'Alto), this quote talks about how it reads ones face emotion. Which brings us to a students emotion and how its read. This is where it is valuable, 'But if you frown, the next ad will be different. "A classroom computer could recognize when a student is becoming counfused or bored," Dr. Huang predicts. Then it could modify the lesson, like an effective human insstructor.'(D'Alto). This is where it is valuable this software, it will be able to tell an instructor their students emotion toward the subject and how they'll be able to improve/modify the lesson. With this software many instructors would be able to improve on their lessons. Thanks to Prof. Thomas Huang and his colleage many students would be able to focus on their lesson and not be bored again. This is why I believe this technology would be a valuable use in a classroom full of students.

Emotions are important factors in many things that people view in today's world. People feel emotions while watching movies, playing games, or even just when having private thoughts. One feels emotion due to the situation they are present in. If a technology can change whatever the person is viewing to something they are satisfied with, that would be great. If the technology is capable of reading a stundent's facial expression to improve upon something, it would be very useful. Using technology to read the emotional expressions of students in a classroom is valuabel due to how it can assist in the students' learning if they are confused and ensure that all students are feeling comfortable in the school environment. It is not unusual that a student can get lost in the middle of a lesson or even feel as the lesson is too simple for him or her. It is important though that steps are taken to resolve the issue that the student is having and offer them the right help. If technology can assist in figuring out whether a student needs help or not, then it is very valuable to a class. In the text, the author states that "A classroom computer could recognize when a student is becoming confused or bored," which displays that the computer can greatly aid the student. If the teacher realizes that a student is confused, the teacher can then go help the student so he or she is no longer lost. The teacher can also make the lesson tougher or more rigorous if a student is becoming too bored. The significant usefulness of the computer displays how such technology can be very valuable to a classroom. Another very valuable reason to have the technology to read facial expression in a classroom is that it can tell when a student is sad or in fear. Being in a safe environment is critical to a student in order to be able to learn without worrying about anything else. It is claimed that the technology, "Using video imagery, the new emotion-recognition software tracks...facial movements," which can be very easily used to recognize when a student is feeling fearful or sad. It is significantly important that the technology can do such thing due to how the text claims that "Most human communication is nonverbal, inlcuding emotional communication," which displays that a student will not most likely inform his or her teacher when he or she are feeling as if they are in danger or if they are sad. Also, the student would not learn as well as he or she would if they are not feeling safe in the classroom. This important use of the technology makes it very valuable to have in a classroom to recognize the facial expressions of the students. These couple of reasons display why having a technology that can read facial expressions of students in a class is valuable. It would be great if it actually does happen in the near future. It would provide assistance to both the students and the teachers by making the right lessons and by ensuring the comfort of everyone within a class. There is already a lot of technology used in classrooms daily to make the students' and the teachers' lives much easier and ensure their success. Using technology to tell the students' emotions can significantly improve upon that process. Overall, the use of technology to improve upon a process is usually a good thing, specially when it aids students and teachers improve classroom experience.

Have you ever just wanted to get in your car with no one but yourself but didn't want to drive? I have, it seems like it would be an interesting thing to do. To many people I'm sure the thought has occured. It seems like such a simple concept, a car with no driver being capable of driving itself, but it isn't. I don't think that driverless cars are the best idea for the world today. I don't think the world is quiet ready to fully grasp the concept of a 100% driverless car. Yes, we have been aware of the concept of a driverless car since 2009 thanks to Google, but I don't think our nation, espically the US because of our very high debt, is in a good enough state to introduce something like the driverless car. Being a teenager in high school, I personally enjoy driving places by myself, so the idea of a fully driverless car simply dosen't apeal to me the way it would to an older man or woman who can't drive well or drive at all. Also, I think it would be a big problem determining who is at fault for the accident when one occurs, the person in the autonomous car or the company who made the car that was responsible for accident. Not knowing who is responsible seems like a lot to worry about, possible lives could be at stake if the wrong choice is made. Cars without a real human driver might be an intertaining thought but I feel they will be very dangerous more often than safe. It is impossible to program a car to have human abilities. The skill and saftey of a human driver would be nearly impossible for anyone to replicate. Driverless cars would hurt our nation more than it would help.

Have you heard of the Facial Action Coding System, also known as FACS? It is technology that can identify human emotions, such as happiness, sadness, anger, fear, disguist, and surprise. This would not be useful in school classrooms on students for many reasons, but it could still be valuable in some situations at school. To begin, one reason the FACS wouldn't be useful to use on school students is because school is for getting an education and learning. School is not for figuring out whether a student is happy or sad, so for that reason the FACS would not be useful. Also using the FACS on students, would take up time and waste it, when students could be learning, which is what they should be doing in school. So basically, the school should be focused on education students, and not trying to tell their emotions using technology. Secondly, the FACS would not be useful because some students may not want it to be used on them. Students don't need a technology to show what emotion they are feeling, when the student their self knows what their current emotions are, and if the school used the FACS it would be a waste of time for the students who didn't need to, want to, or disagree to using the FACS. Also some parents could disagree and not want the school the use the FACS on their students in the school. On the other hand, using the FACS could be valuable. For example if a student is being bullied it would be useful to use in a situation like that. Also it would be useful if a teacher was trying something new in the classroom, and the teacher could see whether her students were happy or not with it. The FACS could also come in handy and be useful and valuable, in acting or drama classes. The FACS could be used to tell how good students are at acting out emotions. In conclusion, using the Facial Action Coding System ( FACS ) can tell emotions such as happiness, sadness, anger,surpise, disguist, and fear. The FACS wouldn't be that valuable at school, because some students may not want others to know their real emotions, and also using the FACS in school would not be valuable because school is for education and learning, not for figuring out emotions. Although the FACs could be valuable to use in school in drama or acting classes to tell how good or bad students are at acting out certain emotions in which they aren't currently feeling.

"Pedestrian, bicycle, private cars, commercial and public transportation traffic are woven into a connected network to save time, conserve resources, lower emissions and improve safety." Owning a vehicle helps get people from one place to another faster then just walking but some people really don't understand that there are advantages to not owning a vehicle. In the excerpts "In German Suburb, life goes on without cars", "The end of car culture" both by Elizbath Rosenthal and "Paris bans driving due to smog" by Robert Duffer, all explain how limiting car usage can help lower emission and conserve resources. In the excerpt "In German Suburb, life goes on without cars" by Elizabeth Rosenthal explains why limiting car usuage would help lower emissions. For example, "Passenger cars are responsible for 12 percent of greenhouse gas emissions in Europe...and up to 50 percent in some car-intensive areas in the United States. Cars are polluting the eniviroment that we all live in and are destroying the atomosphere because of all these greenhouse gases swirling through the air because of the use of cars. Furthermore, referring to another excerpt "The end of car culture" from Elizabeth Rosenthal also, proves why limiting car usuage will lower emission rates. For instance, "What most intrigues me is that rates of car ownership per household and per person started to come down to two to three years before the turndown...it will have beneficial implications for carbon emissions and the enviroment, since transportation is the second largest source of America's emissions, just behind power plants." As you can see owning a car can be a advantage to your personal life but the enviroment is suffering because of the fumes from the vehicles everyone own but if less people start to walk more, ride bikes or even hike the enviroment wouldn't be suffering from so many emissions. Likewise, in the excerpt "Paris bans driving due to smog" by Robert Duffer highlights how limiting car usage can help conserve resources. For example, "After days of near-record polution, Paris enforced a partial driving ban to clear the air of the global city...[The smog] rivaled Beijing, China, which is known as one of the most polluted cities in the world...Cold night and warm days caused the layer of air to trap car emissions." Going back to what Rosental was pointing out emissions are still triggering the atmosphere. But, that is not the only thing that is being blamed for pollution. "Diesel fuel was blamed, since France has...[a] tax policy that favors diesel over gasoline. Diesels make up 67 percent of vehicles in France, compared to a 53.3 percent average of diesel engines in Western Europe, accoring to Reuters." Without any gasoline nobody will be traveling from one place to another so to conserve resources people are better off limiting the usage of their cars. In conclusion, using cars less would help to lower emissions and conserve resources such as in this case gasoline. If everyone keeps driving aroud in cars the air is going to be full of Greenhouse gases and eventually resources to run cars will soon run out. Then without a car to take people where they need to go people will have no choice but to walk, ride a bike, or take public transportaton because everything id worn and ran out. This is why limiting car usage is a advantage for fellow citizens because it helps lower emissions and conserves resources.

Fellow citizens we should limit ower car usage and see the advantages that we can gain from it. Having a car can bring lots of tense and responsibility along with lots of money having to be spent. In (Source 1) it states that "When i had a car I was alwayse tense. I'm much happier this way," Car ownership require lots of of money to be spent on the car,on a garage and even a parcking space. In (Soure 1) it states that "Germany car ownership is allowed, but there are only two places to park-large garages at the edge of the development,where a car-owner buys a space,for $40,000, along with a home". An advantage from limiting your car usage would be to make the cities denser, and better for walking. In (Source 1) it states that "While there have been efforts in the past two decades to make cities denser, and better for walking, planners are now taking the concept to the suburbs".

The question every pereson who is legal to drive "How much you drive is as important as whether you have a hybrid. First and Foremost, Vauban, home to 5,500 residents within a rectangular square mile, may be the most advanced experiment in low-car suburban life. Passengers cars are responsible 12 percent of greenhoudse gas emissions in Europe and up to 50 percent in some car-intensive areas in the United States. Many experts expect public transport serving suburbs to play a larger part in a new six-year federal transportation bill to be approved this year. In previous bills, 80 percent of appropriations have by law gone to highways and only 20 percent to other transport. Next, After days of near-record pollution, paris enforcd a partial driving ban to clear th air of the global city. Motorists with even-numbered license plates were ordered to leve their cars at home or suffer a 22-euro fine ($31). The same would apply to the odd-numbered plate sthe following day. Almost 4,000 drivers were fined according to the international news agency(Reuters). Congestion was down 60 percent in the capital of France,after five -days of intsensifying somg. Diesel fuel was blammed, since France has a tax policy theat favors diesel over gasoline. Paris typically ahs more smog than other European capitals. Las week Paris had 147 microgramsof particulate matter. Public transit was free of charge from Friday to Monday. The somg cleared enough Monday for the ruling French party rescined the ban for odd-numbered plates on tuesday. Last, Recent studies suggest that americans are buying fewer cars, driving less and getting fewer licensices as each year goes by. That has left researchers pondering a fundamental question "Has America passed the peak of driving?" America's love affair with its vehicles seems to be cooling. The United States peaked in 2005 and dropped steadily thereafter. As of April 2013, the number of mile driven per person was nearrly 9 percent below the peak and equal to where the country was in the year 1995. Do you think a programmed computer can actually decipher the emotions of a human being? What about a painting? Can technology deciphering an emotion help our students in their classrom? In today's modern day life technology is used everywhere for everything. Technology seems to excel and expand everyday. We are even up to the point where we have robots working and talking as humans. Even in student classes. Most books are being outdated to computers. Books could be found on line and test can be did online. But could a computer really anayze a student's feelings. The thing is, robots and machines have no emotions. So how would they be able to distinguish a student's emotions, or better yet, a painting's emotions. Even though technology has no emotions, it could decipher a student's emotions through movement of muscles, facial expressions, and emotion recognition software and be very valuable to students in a classroom. Technology or computers can recognize an emotion through your muscles. According to paragraph 3, the process of calculating emotions of a human or painting begins with first uploading a 3-D model of the face. The next step would be to compare the picture with muscles, the picture must move like human muscles. After, technology would relie on facial actions through the FACS, or Facial Action Coding System, to figure out facial movements. The FACS has classified six basic emotions and has associated each with characteristic movements of the facial muscles. With the muscle movement clarrified, the system could connect each facial expression with a movement. And with the new emotion- recgnition sdtware, the software could identify emotions. Thsi could help students in the class by a computer knowing when the student is bored with a lesson or if the student can't concentrate due to tiredness. Although technology can upgrade and use software to decipher's a student's emotions, technology can still be wrong, malfunction, and shutdown on students. A computer is based off of malware, numbers, and software and humans relie on them all the time. Sometimes computers can overwrite or miscalculate signs and give people the wrong expression. The computer can even shutdown completely. But just as a computer could be wrong, so can humans. Humans use calculation everyday. As the example used in paragraph five, we could tell if something is wrong with one of our friends by the look on their face, but most of us would have trouble describing their facial trait. In conclusion, technology can decphier a human's emotions and can be valuable in a classroom. As technology upgrades, students could be able to learn more with the help of computers. Teachers would know whether a student is able to understand the lesson all due to a computer. They also would be able to know if a student is bored or just struggling. This is how technology, being able to read emotional expressions of students, can be valuable.

Dear Mr. Senator, The way the voting is now in the United States needs to be changed. It should change from Electoral College to popular vote. The voting system is an all or nothing system which means lots of peoples votes would not count for the president they want. If the voting system changes the president would actually be picked by the people and not by a group of people who won the popular vote. The electoral college is unfair to many people because their vote goes to waste if the other slate of electors won. In Source 2 it says "On the off-chance that those electors win the statewide election, they would go to Congress and... would get... electoral votes." That is saying that part of the votes would not count because the other group won and not the one they wanted to win. So then the president will get a certain number of electoral votes based on the population of that state. Some people feel like their votes are not needed as much because if the majority of that state chose the other candidate. The electoral college is a good idea, but people can betray the trust of others. In Source 3 it says "...each party selects a slate of electors trusted to vote for the party's nominee..." That means the voters have the ability to vote for the other candidate. If someone decides to vote for the other candidate then some peoples votes will have been for nothing. If we had the popular vote voting system then everyones vote would go to the specific candidate, and people would not have to hope the person they slate they pick has everyone pick the candidate they were trusted to vote for. In the end the voting system of the United States is built on trust. If we have the popular vote voting system everyones vote would go to the candidate that wanted it to go to and not have their vote be wasted on a slate that may or may not win. With the popular voting system the president would win on popular vote and not electoral vote; therefore, the president could not cheat his way to power by targeting big states.

Driverless cars have more negative aspects then positive. I am against the developement of these types of cars. I understand that we need to better our ways of public transportation, but many dangers come with driverless cars and I think that the risks are just not worth it. One negative effect with driverless cars is so far, they do not have the ability to detect when road conditions change from the noraml like road work, traffic jams, or accidents that recently occure. The next major danger of these cars is people's lives could be the effect of an error with the manufacterers. Another aspect is most people who have been driving on their own for a while may not feel comfortable with giving up control to technology. Having driverless cars would take a lot of trust in this technology and that may be a hard thing to accomplish. Driverless cars may not have a positive effect on today's world. Putting people in situations that are extremely risky is not worth being able to sit back and relax while technology is controlling you. The world is modernizing and technology is in practically everything we do, but we have to be focused and in control because putting too much trust into technology that could posibly have faults can become a safety hazard.

Dear Marco Rubio and etc., I think that we should not keep the Electoral College and change to election by popular vote for the sake of the people. With the Electoral College, your voice isn't really heard. Votes should be counted individually and America will get the president that they really want. For starters, there was a situation back in 2000 where Al Gore won the popular vote but didn't become president. That my friend, is unfair. The Electoral College doesn't really prove who actually won. Although, the incident happens back in 1880, I don't think it should happen again. Most of America wouldn't really think of the president as the president. I must admit, the Electoral College is a quick way to send in the votes on election day but it isn't efficient. Like stated in paragraph 10, voters don't vote for the president, but for the state of electors. The electors are basically anyone who isn't holding office. State conventions, state party's central and presidential candidates can pick the electors. Votes can't always control whom their electors vote for which why you should get rid of the Electoral College. Plus it's a dumb name. Another reason why is because the people of this country will be pissed if another Gore vs Bush situation happens again. Electors are really in control, therefor if they dislike who's running against their political party they have a shot at voting for whomever they want. That's unjust, and frankly unfair. Especially if a huge state is at risk. One counterclaim might be that the Electoral College avoids the problem of elections in which no candidate recieves the majority of votes cast. I don't want to vote and wonder if my voice will be heard. I want it to be guarunteed because that's what the United States is all about. It's all about us being able to choose the president. The Electoral College is unjust and is a waste of time. If you guys decide decide on letting us elect the president by popular vote, more young adults will start voting and we'll know out voices are heard.
